{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3412648,"name":"Devin Slattery","username":"Devin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/devin/{size}/174462_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-02T00:06:28.177Z","cooked":"

Over the offseason, we have been working on our next iteration of our shifting swerve and this is our first attempt at this new design.

MSS still render v11016×813 316 KB

Here is the CAD model and ratio sheet we’ve been using.
MSS ratios.xlsx (20.0 KB)

The wheel size and azimuth motor were inspired by REV’s MAXSwerve but the rest was completely redesigned. We decided to design around a Kraken X60 motor for the drive and a Neo 550 with a versa planetary gearbox for the azimuth because we have a large supply of them. It has a range of speeds spanning from 15.3 ft/s-21.5ft/s in high gear and 7ft/s-9.1ft/s in low gear. The wheel is 3D printed and based off of team 88’s 3D printed wheels, modified to be 3” in diameter.

Why Shifting? We have gone with a shifting design for the past 3 games because it gives us a low gear for defense and a high gear for top speed. We also use low gear to save power when accelerating which we have found to be vital in games like 2022 and 2024. In the past we have been traction limited in low gear so we are exploring different tread types to optimize the shifting design.

Dimensions: 5.75” x 5.75” x 8.5” and weighs ~5.5 lbs.

image633×526 76.9 KB

Targeted goals

Summary

The goal of this swerve is to be:

  1.  Lighter

  2.  Smaller

  3.  Cheaper

  4.  More efficient

  5.  Easier to machine

We have accomplished goals 1-3 by switching to a 3” wheel (compared to 5”) and switching away from an inverted motor design. To make it more efficient, we reduced the amount of gears and modified problematic shaft-bearing interactions. The number of machined parts didn’t significantly decrease but complexity of machining each part was decreased.

We have worked on a 3d printed version to make sure everything works/fits in the physical world. We have seen promising performance increases and lessons learned about the swerve.

3d printed swerve1920×2560 368 KB

If you have any questions or feedback we would greatly appreciate it.

Awesome! Any chance you can share that 3 in wheel and elaborate on changes from the OG 88 wheel version?

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-08-02T00:28:09.052Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":536,"readers_count":535,"score":112.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":469420,"topic_slug":"mini-shifting-swerve","display_username":"Cory Walters","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22243,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/mini-shifting-swerve/469420/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3412659,"name":"Devin Slattery","username":"Devin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/devin/{size}/174462_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-02T02:02:05.808Z","cooked":"

Sure! (Step File)
The wheel was designed from scratch with the help of 88’s dimensions (mainly for the compression “spokes” and tread “spikes”). The major change is it uses a thrifty bot 45t, 1.25 module, bevel gear. It also uses different bearings than SDS modules. There hasn’t been any traction, compression, or wear tests yet, but we didn’t stray far from the original design.

1.25 module","clicks":9},{"url":"https://drive.google.com/file/d/1ufVLzmO8tUvtsckVgd1pRKGUizui7PUq/view?usp=sharing","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"3 inch tpu wheel.step - Google Drive","clicks":6},{"url":"https://www.vexrobotics.com/pro-bearings.html?config=273-1281,274-1284,275-1288,279-1307","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":5}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":22243,"username":"Cory_Walters","name":"Cory Walters","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cory_walters/{size}/7329_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53790,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4265 Design & Engineering Lead"},"post_url":"/t/mini-shifting-swerve/469420/3","custom_user_title":"4265 Design & Engineering Lead","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3412663,"name":"Connor O'Sullivan","username":"Connor_OSullivan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/ea666f/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-08-02T02:29:38.775Z","cooked":"

Have you had any problems with rough shifting or anything breaking unexpectedly? It was mentioned that your team has been using shifting swerve for a few seasons and I am just mainly wondering how it has been holding up during tough matches.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-08-02T02:29:38.775Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":474,"readers_count":473,"score":114.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":469420,"topic_slug":"mini-shifting-swerve","display_username":"Connor O'Sullivan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":67388,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/mini-shifting-swerve/469420/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3412667,"name":"Devin Slattery","username":"Devin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/devin/{size}/174462_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-02T03:01:14.879Z","cooked":"

If the shifters are greased properly, the shifting is pretty smooth; but we have found that after a while (normally in the offseason) the shifting get a little rough. We believe it is a lack of grease/maintenance. We have had different damage/failure issues with each type of swerve. With the non inverted design, we had damage to the center “teeter totter” piston transfer. The inverted design had less “impact” damage but the added parts caused more failure points. The main purpose of the “teeter totter” was to have a shifter sensor (helps with odometry) but we have switched to built in hall effect sensors in the piston. This new design should keep the piston/sensors more protected and hopefully more robust.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-08-02T03:01:14.879Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":450,"readers_count":449,"score":95.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":469420,"topic_slug":"mini-shifting-swerve","display_username":"Devin Slattery","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/frc-4265-secret-city-wildbots-shifting-swerve-cad-release/398843","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"FRC 4265 Secret City Wildbots Shifting Swerve CAD Release","clicks":26}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":67388,"username":"Connor_OSullivan","name":"Connor O'Sullivan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/ea666f/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53790,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4265 Design & Engineering Lead"},"post_url":"/t/mini-shifting-swerve/469420/5","custom_user_title":"4265 Design & Engineering Lead","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3412858,"name":"sam liu","username":"catrix","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/dbc845/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-08-03T06:34:16.161Z","cooked":"

I’m curious how the code for shifting swerve work. Do all the modules shift at the same time or each one of them shift independently according to its own module speed?

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-08-03T06:34:16.161Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":329,"readers_count":328,"score":100.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":469420,"topic_slug":"mini-shifting-swerve","display_username":"sam liu","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60033,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"CE Student @ UWaterloo | 5516 Alum "},"post_url":"/t/mini-shifting-swerve/469420/6","custom_user_title":"CE Student @ UWaterloo | 5516 Alum ","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3412872,"name":"viggy96","username":"viggy96","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/viggy96/{size}/252784_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-03T13:36:36.355Z","cooked":"

Would be relatively simple to have each module have its own shifting algorithm, and automatically shift based on speed, with some hysteresis to prevent rapid shifting back and forth between gears.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-08-03T13:36:36.355Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":307,"readers_count":306,"score":91.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":469420,"topic_slug":"mini-shifting-swerve","display_username":"viggy96","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":60033,"username":"catrix","name":"sam liu","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/dbc845/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24613,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"418 Mentor | Tries to be smart"},"post_url":"/t/mini-shifting-swerve/469420/7","custom_user_title":"418 Mentor | Tries to be smart","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3413125,"name":"Devin Slattery","username":"Devin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/devin/{size}/174462_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-04T13:29:46.433Z","cooked":"

@viggy96 nailed it. All of the modules shift depending on their motor velocity but we also have a “force downshift” button for pushing or low speed control. When decelerating we only shift back down to low gear once the robot has come close to a stop.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-08-04T13:29:46.433Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":258,"readers_count":257,"score":106.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":469420,"topic_slug":"mini-shifting-swerve","display_username":"Devin Slattery","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":60033,"username":"catrix","name":"sam liu","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/dbc845/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53790,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4265 Design & Engineering Lead"},"post_url":"/t/mini-shifting-swerve/469420/8","custom_user_title":"4265 Design & Engineering Lead","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3413134,"name":"","username":"httpmaster","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/h/ebca7d/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-08-04T14:46:21.601Z","cooked":"

I am part of a team that has switched to fully electric. Is there a way to (Frc legally) switch this design to use an electric solenoid? I love the idea of a shifting swerve, and have been thinking about doing one for a while. Great job with the design! I’m also wondering on wether you are planning to release more documentation on how to recreate this.

Do you guys match speed when shifting? As in, does your shifting algorithm adjust motor output to match wheel speed in high gear to the speed in low gear just prior to the shift.

Would be nice to see more shifting gearboxes use an electrical solenoid actuator instead of a pneumatic piston in general.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-08-04T15:41:00.883Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":221,"readers_count":220,"score":44.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":469420,"topic_slug":"mini-shifting-swerve","display_username":"viggy96","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":67339,"username":"httpmaster","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/h/ebca7d/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24613,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"418 Mentor | Tries to be smart"},"post_url":"/t/mini-shifting-swerve/469420/11","custom_user_title":"418 Mentor | Tries to be smart","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3413155,"name":"Devin Slattery","username":"Devin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/devin/{size}/174462_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-04T16:35:21.224Z","cooked":"

There’s nothing to my knowledge that is stopping you from using an electric mechanism but we don’t for 3 reasons: size, force, and speed. Pistons are relatively small, output a ton of force, and are really fast; additionally they are pretty robust. We like to shift often so the speed/force of a small electric actuator wouldn’t work for us. It isn’t in the CAD model but to connect to the shifter coupler you just need a 10/32 nut on a bolt so that shouldn’t be an issue.

We don’t usually make assembly guides but we would be open to sharing a BOM (still working on it) and answering any questions you have.

Short answer no.

As the module is accelerating, the module chooses to shift once the RPM gets high enough. While the shifter is in between high and low, the motor maintains its speed until the shifter engages at which point the motor is pulled down to a lower speed. The code corrects after the fact to account for this. In an ideal world, we would make it so that the motor switches to coast while transitioning and adjusts immediately after, but the lag time for the hall effect sensors takes too long to realistically do that.

Definitely some fudging the numbers but it isn’t that bad. We assume that the modules maintain their velocity while shifting and we use that for the odometry (even thought this isn’t technically true, it’s close enough). Unfortunately the modules take around a half second to shift which is a pretty long time. We currently check when it starts shifting, latch the velocity while shifting, and then resume using real values once it’s engaged. Naturally, this is also done on a per module basis because shifting is done individually by module.

","post_number":16,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-08-04T20:04:24.211Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":15,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":194,"readers_count":193,"score":43.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":469420,"topic_slug":"mini-shifting-swerve","display_username":"Silas Rowden","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":19235,"username":"Skyehawk","name":"Skye Leake","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55316,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4265 Programming Lead"},"post_url":"/t/mini-shifting-swerve/469420/16","custom_user_title":"4265 Programming Lead","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3413225,"name":"Devin Slattery","username":"Devin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/devin/{size}/174462_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-04T20:40:50.996Z","cooked":"

The last time we used a COTS swerve was 2020 and that was beyond my time so take this with a gain of salt.
Cons: It is less efficient than COTS swerves because of the shifter and extra set of gears on it; our non inverted design (2022) saw a drop of ~2ft/s and our inverted design (2023-24) saw a drop of ~4ft/s (from theoretical free speed). They are more prone to breaking because there are more moving parts. We’ve had issues with odometry when constantly shifting and not in view of April tags. Lastly, you have to re machine and assemble them in season which can be challenging depending on your team size.

Pros: Pushing through defense or robots in your way: at RCR we had defense near the feeder station and we could push right through them without browning out. Accelerating consumes less energy when shifting. Lastly, its a good challenge for students and it always impresses the judges as custom drive trains become less common.

","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-08-04T20:40:50.996Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":14,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":181,"readers_count":180,"score":36.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":469420,"topic_slug":"mini-shifting-swerve","display_username":"Devin Slattery","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":26167,"username":"FerMtz","name":"FerMtz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fermtz/{size}/186881_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53790,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4265 Design & Engineering Lead"},"post_url":"/t/mini-shifting-swerve/469420/17","custom_user_title":"4265 Design & Engineering Lead","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3413230,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-04T20:59:16.877Z","cooked":"

Makes me wonder if a few things would help in any way in the real world. As a thought experiment:

  • only shifting if the velocity seems stable, which is already sort of - if not explicitly - done based on my understanding. Extending this, only shift when the instantanious torque on the drive motor is (near) zero, this may only need to happen in one direction based on ball shifters, or both ways based on dog shifters.

  • address the shifting speed mechanically. As the modules are not constantly shifting you could preload the energy to do it faster and trigger it to shift however you like.

","post_number":18,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-08-04T21:03:44.756Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":16,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":182,"readers_count":181,"score":41.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":469420,"topic_slug":"mini-shifting-swerve","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":55316,"username":"SilasRowden","name":"Silas Rowden","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/silasrowden/{size}/231049_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/mini-shifting-swerve/469420/18","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3413558,"name":"Silas Rowden","username":"SilasRowden","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/silasrowden/{size}/231049_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-05T23:58:28.067Z","cooked":"

I will definitely take a look at when we shift and how. It makes sense that the velocity should be stable so that there is no discrepancy in energy conversion between gears. I will also probably be adding code for putting the motor in coast while shifting to reduce module wear due to forcibly slowing the motor while engaging the gears. I’m not sure about the mechanical solution you mentioned but that isn’t my area of expertise anyway so I’ll leave it to mechanical people.

Just fyi, all of our code is available to anyone (although it is currently in LabVIEW) for shifting swerves so feel free to take a look if you are ever curious and ask any questions if you’re curious.
